Great professor. Although lectures can go pretty fast, if you prepare beforehand you'll be okay. He values helping his students very highly, as long as you are putting in effort. The class wasn't easy, but no orgo chem class will be. I highly recommend him.

Dr. Chang was a great prof who truly cares for his students. He tries his best to prepare everyone for the common exams, which are about the same level as his quizzes and recitation worksheets. His lectures go fast but go to office hours, read Ochem as a 2nd Language, and watch lots of youtube videos. Also lots of extra credit with recitation!

Dr. Chang has to be my favorite professor I've had in college. He is definitely not easy on his students, but it's for a reason. He gives everyone an opportunity to succeed, but makes you work for the grade you earn. His classes tend to have very smart people so it gets competitive. Such a fun guy though, I can't recommend him enough.

Dr. Chang is a good guy and a caring prof. He really wants you to succeed, and gives you the materials to do so, which is why I chose to do both semesters of ochem with him. My only complaint was that his pre-covid practice quizzes/exams did not prepare you for his online exams, though I definitely see why the online versions had to be harder.

Dr. Chang is very thorough in his lectures so be sure to attend and stay after class as he takes the time to answer extra questions. Quizzes and exams are formatted similar so practicing quizzes and the worksheets offered are best practice for exam. Not the nicest person but somewhat generous. Drops lowest two quizzes and curves very well.
Dr. Chang is great and I felt like I really understood ochem concepts because of his teaching. Aa long as you attend all lectures and do the homework and practice you can do will with him.

Organic Chemistry is a very difficult class. Dr. Chang gives lots of material to help study and he is very helpful during office hours. His exams and quizzes aren't too hard. I recommend practicing the old ones he gives you for practice as well as the recitation activities ;) The TA's can be somewhat confusing on some things so go to Chang first.

Easily the best professor I have ever had. I took 2510 and 2520 with him and he does an amazing job at taking very abstract and difficult concepts and breaking them into memorable metaphors. Be prepared to easily spend 10+ hours a week on Ochem alone, especially 2520. Exams are hard and make you think, but he draws mostly from practice materials.

Dr. Chang is the best ochem prof at OSU. Eventhough he has an accent, he teaches the material very well, is very nice and funny, and his test questions are very clear and straightforward (unlike other professors). He also gave us extra credit and had a lot of office hours.

Amazing! Best ochem professor at OSU. English isnt perfect but he does his best to speak loud/clear and repeat things multiple times. Gives funny analogies to help students understand reaction conditions and mechanisms. Very fair and genuinely wants his students to do well. Lots of study resources. He makes sure hard work  success in his class.
Wallah my favorite teacher. I hate my teachers now I would retake his Ochem class again just for fun if I could. He made me love Ochem

Dr. Chang is honestly awesome. I retook this class after failing with Callam and Dr. Chang's exams are EXTREMELY reasonable. He tells you what's on the exam and the questions come from his question sets. Aside from that, he's kind, wants you to succeed, & makes time at the beginning of class for questions. Also, good curve!! TAKE HIM!

Dr. Chang's lectures were very organized. Lecture is extremely important and I don't think you could do very well in the class if you didn't go to lecture. Practice exams are very helpful in preparing for the exams. Dr. Chang is EXTREMELY straightforward in what he will ask you on the exam.

He is one of the better ochem profs, but he does not see mental illness as a real issue. He is not American and people from his culture do undermine mental illness. If you do struggle with ADHD, anxiety, or depression. Look for a different prof

Dr. Chang is the best!! Such a caring guy, who genuinely wants his students to succeed. A lot of the test questions are very similar or identical to past quizzes and worksheets and lecture examples. So if you study, you will do well.

His lectures are better than the other Ochem profs, but his exams will have a lot of things on there that was barely touched in class. Averages are around 50-65 percent, which is still awful. He puts the 2nd midterm and final VERY close!! Everyone was very rushed for the final and many students did poorly. He gives a 10% so 50% u will not pass

Dr. Chang is the best combo of a great professor from whom you'll learn a lot, and easy grading criteria that you will find in from an Ochem professor. Dr. Chang gives weekly extra credit, and many of his exam questions come straight from quizzes and homework. His class is still a lot of work, but take him at all cost if it fits your schedule.

Organic chemistry is hard, but Dr. Chang really tries his best to make it as understandable as possible. He reads multiple textbooks and summarizes the information for you in a clear way. Go to all the office hours you can, too! He's really personable and wants you to succeed. The curve was kind but you do have to work for it.

Dr. Chang is a great professor. As tough as Organic chemistry is, he truly makes this class as fair as possible. This is shown through multiple ways such as how he gives extra credit and numerous amount of practice problems. Although, I will say that his class is very lecture based so skipping them is not a good idea.

Dr. Chang is one of the most caring professors I've had thus far. He is so helpful in office hours (which I highly recommend attending) and is great at explaining things in lecture. He also gives a TON of extra credit for those who participate in class and recitation. He has high expectations, but he makes it easy to succeed in this class.

Dr. Chang teaches a tough class and has high expectations, but he does his best to help students be successful. His lectures are clear (no textbook needed - he gives you all the info and practice problems that you need). He also is very helpful in office hours. He expects students to put in the work, but he will do whatever he can to help.

Dr. Chang provides all of the resources you need to do well in the class. If you consistently review your notes, the recitation packets, and the problem sets, it is definitely doable to get an A. Compared to other Ochem instructors at OSU, he is much more straightforward and he is also pretty funny as well and keeps students fairly engaged.

He keeps tests as fair as possible and avoids ambiguity or exceptionally tricky questions. He REALLY CARES about students and is willing to do anything to help you understand the content. A downside of taking him is that he's not very good with explaining some ideas as he isn't very good with words.

I loved having Chang for ochem 1. The tests are hard, but the problem sets and recitation activities he gives you are really good prep. If you know how to do those, you should be fine. Go to lecture because he doesn't post most of his lecture notes on Carmen. Very accessible - has multiple office hours a week and works one on one with you.
Fantastic teacher. Tons of practice problems. No surprises. Always available to help.

Ochem is a hard class and Dr. Chang does his best to make it better. He genuinely cares about student's and does anything he can to help. His notes are very detailed and only available in class if you attend it. Don't skip class! Go to office hours for help. He really cares about you.
Very kind and caring professor, in my opinion one of the best ochem professors you could have at OSU. Wish I could have hime again for 2520 just wouldn't work for my schedule :/
The worst teacher I've ever met

Dr. Chang is an amazing, funny, and helpful professor who wants to see his students succeed. That being said, you need to attend lecture and write down ALL of his notes because his exam questions come directly from the lecture notes/examples. Go to office hours; you will get lots of help and hints from him. There is extra credit offered as well.
Probably the best Ochem professor there is. If you have a chance, definitely take him. Super caring and makes the class hilarious yet informative.

Great professor, lectures are down to earth and Chang makes things easy to understand just make sure you pay attention and take good notes.  Gives lots of resources to students and always there for your success.

Dr. Chang is easily one of my favorite professors ever. He is really funny. He would always come up with funny analogies that make the chemistry make more sense. GO TO OFFICE HOURS!!! He gives out a lot of extra points in recitation and his exams are tough but fair. You will earn the grade for the work you put into the class.

Dr. Chang is amazing. He's funny and really cares about students. He offers extra credit opportunities and helps students whenever needed. He also asks for questions at the beginning, during, and end of lecture. I've learned a ton more from this professor than I have from any chemistry professor. Attendance is not mandatory, but highly recommended.

Dr. Chang is one of the best professors I've had so far. In the beginning his accent makes understanding hard but you get used to it fast. He is unambiguous about what's going to be on the exam, gives a lot of extra credit and genuinely wants to help his students succeed. He is sooo hilarious in class. LOVED HIM

Dr. Chang is a very fair grader. He tells you what to expect on the exams and gives you materials to succeed in his course including a lot of practice problems. He is entertaining in lecture. He even gave out free frosty coupons to people who answered. Overall, great professor, very helpful. Would take again. Love this man.

Dr. Chang really cares about his students and wants to make sure they understand the topics. He offers a lot of extra practice and handouts on Carmen. Exams are fair. I took entire weekends off to prepare for his 2 Monday midterms and just repeated practice problems over and over. There is also extra credit. He's a funny guy and made ochem fun

Besides his accent he is very clear and explains concepts well. Holds lots of office hours, highly recommend to go to as many as possible. Gives extra credit on exam and does lecture mistakes that are worth extra credit. Going to class EVERY DAY is a must to do well in his class. The book is not 100% needed, but at least know someone that has it.

Dr. Chang is one of my favorite professors thus far. He is incredibly helpful--office hours are invaluable and he also presents plenty of study materials. This is by no means an easy subject but if you put in the time, Dr. Chang will make getting a good grade possible. Bonus: he gives A TON of extra credit.

Dr. Chang is my favorite professor here at Ohio State.  He genuinely cares and wants to help out his students.  He gives out tons of bonus, around 100 points.  He makes the lectures very interesting.  Don't listen to what people say about his clarity, he goes fast at times but he is clear on what you need to know  wait a semester for him if you can

Extremely hard to understand at times. I spent more time trying to piece together the broken English than understanding material. Practically taught myself as he was an almost entirely useless resource. Easy grading scale just to make up for the fact that he is just awful at teaching. You won't understand anything unless you're a good self teacher.

Chang was an amazing professor. I thought his handwriting was neat and his notes are point on. Lectures are very helpful. He is very eager to help students and wants them to do good. Exams are pretty fair and not difficult if you study and prepare for them well.
Attend office hours and it will change your grade. A great guy who really cares about the material, pay attention to his lectures!

He is crystal clear in what he wants you to know for midterms and for the final he gives a deatiled breakdown of the things that are on the final. In additon for the midterms he tells you in class exactly what is on them even telling you that specific examples verbatim are on there. Up to 120 points of extra credit. Easy A if u do the work.

Dr. Chang is the best ochem professor at OSU. A ton of extra credit, a lot of practice problems on Carmen, which no other professors offer for their students. Big curve at end of class. Tells you exactly what will be on the midterms and final. Doesn't put anything that isn't in his notes. Do not skip class. Start studying a week before the tests.
He is hard to understand and his writing his hard to read.

Dr. Chang has definitely been one of my favorite professors so far. He worries more than the students sometimes about their grades and is very clear. His class is challenging, but if you use the resources he gives you, the class is not a problem at all. He makes O. Chem super interesting and cuts out all the unnecessary material. Would recommend.
Dr. Chang is extremely approachable and eager to help his students be as prepared as possible for everything that comes at them. His course was wonderful!

Great professor, very tough class. O-chem is difficult, but prof. Chang is by far the best professor to take at OSU, he offers the most extra credit, and he cares a ton about his students and making sure they understand the material. He also provides lots of extra materials (problem sets, notes, etc.) to give students ample tools to study with.

Chang is super helpful and a very good professor. If you attend lectures and do all the recitation problem sets and HW you will receive a fair grade in his class. He gives a lot of opportunities for bonus points and runs the class well.

Okay, so I didn't do well. I got a C+, but I had to do a lot of extra credit to get it. This guy challenged me and made me work my butt off. If I studied more, I'm sure I could have gotten an A. He's sometimes hard to understand but always makes sure to correct himself to get his message across. Cool guy, and he sometimes stressed more than we did.

Funny nice guy, but his Midterms are RIDICULOUS. honestly i would drop out of his class and try another teacher. Our class averages were in the 40-50% and the other organic chemistry teacher was in the 70-80%

Dr Chang is Awesome. His lectures are very thorough and in-depth. His exams and quizzes are difficult but he provides his old tests and quizzes which we HAVE to do in order to succeed. His lecture notes are way more important than the book.

Excellent professor who is always willing to help. His midterms are tough but if you work hard on his materials, you will do perfectly fine. Make sure you score his extra credit opportunities in which you'll be required to correct his 'lecture mistakes'. Don't be surprised that these bonus points will boost your final grade.

Dr. Chang is a great professor. He really cares about his students and their success in his class. The material is very tough but he explains it as clearly as possible, do the problem sets and study his notes front and back and you will do great!
Great professor who really cares about his students! Very willing to help. His office hours are very helpful and lectures are definitely worth attuning. Overall great professor!

Dr. Chang is very well organized and a funny guy. I would have really liked him as a professor if it weren't for two major shortcomings. Dr. Chang goes WAY TOO FAST in lectures. He is very hard to keep up with if you take notes, making it hard to learn from his lectures. He also often overestimates the learning ability of students

Dr. Chang was a VERY good professor for ochem. He was super approachable and it was obvious he cared about his students and how they were doing in the class. His exams were hard, but completely fair. He also had a lot of opportunities for us to get extra credit, which was super helpful!
He is a very nice and approachable professor, and has a very organized set up to his class. his notes are very helpful and clear.

Very helpful teacher. Makes things clear and easy to understand. Exams are fair and similar to practice exams. Attendance is recommended. He gives you descriptions on what he expects you to know for the exams. I was never good at Chemistry, but I was able to do well in this class.
Such a good professor! He's very helpful and his exams are extremely fair. Just STUDY! If you don't study organic chem and get a poor grade it's your own fault, especially in his class.

Dr. Chang is a great lecturer. He repeats things more than once, and he is very helpful during office hours. Do all of his problem sets multiple times before exams, and study for the recommended amount of time (15 hours per week). The exams are hard, but very doable. Just know your material!!!
Great instructor, works hard to explain the material.

Seems to teach in a round about way, but pretty clear overall.  His exams will frequently have little easy to miss trip ups such as a negative sign. Exam 3 was unreasonable as it was a multiple choice where you would answer one question and the next 3 would depend on that answer. No partial credit given.

Dr. Chang is definitely an accessible professor; he answers emails and stays after class to answer questions. His tests are very difficult. However, he does teach by the book & lectures slides. To get an A, read the book, know the slides, know the notes, and be able to answer end of chapter questions in the book. Hardest examples appear on exams!

Chang is awesome. He is very interesting in lecture and makes jokes. His tests are hard, but if you take the time to study you'll be fine. Lecture is not mandatory. I skipped over half the lectures and still got above average on every exam.

Dr. Chang is a great professor: he teaches the material very well and really cares about all of his students. If you put in hard work, keep up with the material, and ask questions you will do very well in his class. His exams are very fair and going to lecture will really help you succeed on his exams.
Funny lecturer, but the first exam was quite hard. Later, he made the exam easier to help the grade. He's a fan of Buckeye's too!
Hard class, but Dr Chang does his best to make it easy. Willing to go the extra mile to help students comprehend the material.

Dr. Chang is a great professor.  He is genuinely interested in helping you and came to class prepared and organized.  His notes were easy to follow and clear.  He is not necessarily easy, but if you pay attention to what he tells you will be on the test you will do fine.  I never once cracked the text book and did well in his class.

One of the best profs I've ever had. OSU should hire more people like Dr. Chang who really cares about students. I worked 2 jobs to pay for my tuition and I feel my money is worth it because this guy cares about the course. If you just want to get an easy grade, he is not your option. If you really wanna learn, I'd rec him.

Really passionate about the class and is super nice! Theres a big curve because his exams are hard. but if you go to lecture and complete aleks and utilize CE 160 for labs you will be golden no matter how you do on your tests.

Chang is a good teacher, but it's very hard to get an A in this class. You must go to class every day and take notes, he'll give you hints in class for tests so make sure to pay attention. Overall good teacher, just a difficult class.

A very difficult class, but a great professor. Always willing and wanting to help his students succeed. Often criticized for having outrageous tests that are impossible to study for. It's true his tests are difficult, but he tells you precisely what to study and tests off his notes. It's really not that hard to know what will be on it.

Very helpful professor! Gives many example problems in class and keeps that class interesting and durable. Often times he stars questions which will be on the midterms/final and overall lets you know what you need to know. Great professor. Very helpful. Would definitely recommend to take

He is a nice guy and I enjoyed his lectures. However, you never know what is going to be on the exams. The practice exams are 100% easier than the real one and he puts every exception possible. When he says that a question will be on a midterm, exactly, prepare for one with half the information missing. I would not take another class with him.

Overall a great teacher. Very devoted to his work and interested in seeing his students succeed. Bottom line, if you put the effort forth to pass, you will. If you think you can coast by and rely on the curve, you may get lucky and pass but your GPA will more than likely suffer. Study his practice midterms and finals,  some q's in exact format!

This was probably one of the hardest classes I've taken at OSU but Dr. Chang was easily one of the best professors I've EVER had.  I learned so much from his class and his enthusiasm and love for teaching and chemistry were beyond infectious.  He was extremely clear and taught extremely well!

Dr. Chang was very enthusiastic about his job, and the labs, quizzes, and Aleks were great tools in learning the material. However, there was no way to prepare for exams as the online practices were 100% different. The midterms and finals were very difficult. I would recommend going to lecture even though he is hard to understand.

Very nice guy.  Hard to understand and no way to prepare for the midterms and finals.  Do aleks.  The quizzes are easy and so are the labs if you try.  Just try your best on the midterms and finals and know ever exception to every trend.  I recommend doing the problems within each chapter of the book to see if you know the main idea.

The guy's hilarious and enthusiastic about his subject. Format the information's presented in isn't very helpful. Quizzes are easy, midterms are pretty tough and very different from the online practice, lots of minute details, but they're also curved a ton. as long as you prepare for the labs they're not bad and not much work outside of labs.

Yiiiikes! To my fellow pre-med majors I wish you well. He is a rough test maker and will have midterms averaging around 50%. His lectures are incredibly hard to follow, though I would recommend going as much as you can stand. If you can avoid DO IT, but you may be able to fight through it.

Chang is an awful lecturer. Going to lecture is rather pointless. You basically end up trying to figure out what all of the test and quiz questions will be in order to pass instead of actually learning anything (since he can't articulate himself very well). I love chemistry, but listening to Chang's lecture made me reconsider being a science major.
Dr. Chang is the most organized professor I have ever had. He is always well-prepared for lectures. I would highly recommend him.

He is very knowledgeable in chemistry, but he has a difficult time articulating his thoughts in English.  He doesn't know how to explain things in a way for students to understand.  I had a hard time understanding basic concepts with him.

Dr Chang is absolutely terrible.  I attended every lecture, took good notes, studied frequently, and still found myself struggling with everything in the class.  Chemistry took up so much of my time and forced me to focus less on other classes.  I now hate the subject and refuse to take any more related courses.

Can't stand anything about this course, one of the main reasons being Dr. Chang.  When you aren't hurrying to finish the extremely difficult labs, you're studying aimlessly to understand what hasn't been taught to you.  Avoid this at all costs.

Kind of hard to understand his accent, went kind of quickly through difficult mechanisms. Posts ppts online, but still has blanks on them even if not covered in class. A little easier than 245 though. Try to get a clearer speaking prof if possible; Chang was only option for summer lab.
Very difficult. 1/3 of students don't pass every quarter, I was one of them- so watch out!!

Good Professor.  His notes and lecture slides are your study guide.  Sometimes uses example from lecture in his quizzes and midterms.  Very tough midterms. Average was a 53% on Midterm I.  Work hard, study hard, go to lecture, do a lot of practice problems, and you will do well in his class.

Very good professor.  For 122 his notes are your life.  Does tons of problems on board and is very helpful during office hours. GO TO LECTURE, a little hard to understand sometimes, but overall very good.  Tells you exactly what types of problems will be on tests and quizzes.

Dr. Chang is a nice and helpful professor. He usually just reads his notes in class, so you can just get the same information online and not have to attend lecture, especially if you're familiar with the material. The exams and quizzes were unpleasant, so it would've been nice if he had homework grades to balance those out.

Dr. Chang is a very nice guy who is genuinely interested in chemistry, although he does not make a good professor at all.  His quizzes and tests are absolutely impossible and his lectures are not helpful.

Dr Chang is a good and very intelligent man. However, the class was incredibly difficult. I ended up with 2 A's the quarter, and I got a C- in this one. There is a reason why the Chem department at OSU is notorious. Simply put, this class is hard, and the tests are impossible.

He's a nice guy. Kind of hard to follow during his lectures, b/c he literally FLIES through his powerpoints...if you prepare for his lectures and review after lectures, it will help alot. so definately spend lot of time for his class..first midterm's avg was 55%

Nice guy, horrible lecturer. He literally reads directly from prepared power points. Rarely does he work out a problem on the board. Take anyone else for 122. This was his first quarter teaching, so maybe he will get better. You will need to read the book if you take him. I recommend doing all the problems and self tests to help you learn.

Dr. Chang is nice, but that's where the pluses end. He's very insensitive and completely ruled by his superiors. His teaching style is not helpful at all and his exams and quizzes are impossible. OSU's chem department sucks, and this prof is no exception.
Dr. Chang is a super nice guy but honestly, I learned more reading the book and doing the problems on my own than from lecture.  Exams and quizzes are really, really hard.

Dr. Chang means well, but definitely hasn't grasped the ability to teach well at all.  You absolutely have to print slides even if you usually take notes because he moves through them so fast.  His quizzes are hard and exams are nothing like the practice exams.  First avg was a 47%.  He gives you no time to absorb what he "teaches" at you.

Dr. Chang is a terrible professor. He doesn't make any sense and his teaching style makes it useless to attend lecture.  He has weekly quizzes, which are hard, and midterms that are impossible.  I mean only 4 people out of 230 got above a 69 percent.  Unless you were born as a general chemistry prodigy, you won't do well. Zellmer is much better.

Dr. Chang is very friendly and explains concepts and problems well.  He is also helpful when he comes through lab.  His exams are very difficult - the class average for the first exam was a 46.  However as a lecturer, he is very good and helpful.
Very professinal, amiable, very entertaining. Enjoyed lecture. Difficult exams, but nothing unreasonable.

summary_comment: Dr. Bandara is an exceptionally gifted and passionate instructor who brings a high level of engagement to his analytical chemistry course, making even potentially dull topics interesting. Despite being a relatively new teacher, he is highly accessible and provides numerous opportunities for extra credit. While his slides can be cluttered, they are generally helpful, and exams are fair with easy practice tests available.

Ratings.comment: Even though he has not been teaching that long, Dr. Bandara is an incredibly gifted instructor. He is very passionate about the subject, and is always accessible. Exams were fair, not that much HW.

Dr. Bandara is clearly interested in analytical chemistry which makes a very boring class more engaging. His slides are a little cluttered but I still found them to be helpful. Exams were very easy and practice tests were a helpful study tool. He gives ample opportunities for easy extra credit. There is an annoying group paper but it's not too bad.

summary_comment: Professor Zellmer's class is known for its challenging yet engaging content, with rigorous weekly quizzes and extensive homework that prepare students well for exams. While some find the workload overwhelming and the lecture style outdated, many appreciate his dedication to student success and the thorough preparation he provides. Overall, his teaching approach is demanding but considered worthwhile by those who persist through the challenges.

Ratings.comment: This guy gave me a bad score!

Professor Zellmer's class is challenging, but engaging. The weekly quizzes and homework can be time-consuming, but they really help prep for the exams. I found tools like unstuckstudy ai and the free textbook essential for staying on top of the material. Overall, a tough but worthwhile course.

If you fear this man, fear no more because he retired at the end of last semester.

But I must say, the Sunday night quizzes and the insane amounts of homework are necessary. I'm kinda thankful because they allowed me to fail softly, then succeed on exams. This guy always encouraged his students to practice problems like crazy before the exams.

Don't be scared by what people say, Zellmer is great and really wants to see students succeed. Yes, Sunday quizzes aren't the best but they help to prep for exams, and yes there are a lot of emails every day. He covers a lot in lecture so skipping is gonna set you back big time. He's tough but he also clearly loves teaching.

Dr. Zellmer assigns so much homework a week it is unmanageable. He is also the only professor that gives Sunday quizzes that heavily weigh on your grade. The quizzes are also only open from 7-10pm on Sundays. His lecture style is out of date and there are better Chem 2 professors. I would avoid Dr. Zellmer if I could have.

Very blunt and sarcastic. Cool chemical demonstrations in class. Lecture style was hand-written problems he wouldn't explain all the way, super confusing. I just did everything by the book and skipped lectures. Homework every Fri+Sat, quizzes Sun night. Gives you lots of material to prepare you but you have to learn it by yourself.
Although I get A- but that is because in the lab section I lost a lot of points. The professor zellmer is the best!

Dr. Zellmer will sit and lecture only to give exams with significantly harder material than taught. His class is hard and he is the only section with 40-point Sunday night quizzes that will significantly impact your grade even when he says they won't. Do not take this class with him, find someone who cares if you do well!!

Cons: significantly more homework than for other lecturers, and quizzes every Sunday. Pros: the increased workload prepares you more for exams, and Zellmer is a brilliant (and funny) lecturer. The exam averages were high 60s to low 70s, and the class has only a minimal curve. So be prepared to study hard for a good grade

Yes, there is lots of homework and Sunday night quizzes, but Dr. Zellmer gives students all of the materials they need to get an A in the course.  The fact of the matter is whether students actually put in the effort to get an A.

Dr Zellmer is a nice guy. He does assign quizzes every Sunday in a two hour window. While also having online chemistry homework every friday and saturday. Its a lot of work. Go to lecture. Do not take this class unless you need it. It really sucks. But hope you have Zellmer

Dr. Zellmer is a good professor who clearly cares for his students. (creating a whole website for his classes filled to the brim with study materials.) However, in his class there were quizzes that none of the other sections had.

He is condescending, but watch the how to learn video. He is giving you the key to the class. The Sunday quizzes suck but they help you prepare for the exam, if you see this, watch the how to learn video do not wait to do poor on the first midterm to watch it. Go to lecture and ask questions in office hours or emails. It is a lot of work daily.

If you can avoid this professor at all costs. He gives so many assignments every week on top of a weekly Sunday quiz. Some of the quizzes aren't too hard but you really have to study for them and if do badly on the quizzes they will definitely tank your grade. Also, his lectures are kind of a waste of time since his powerpoints make no sense.

Awful teacher 

A jerk

Avoid at all cost

Chem 1220 is no doubt a hard class, but Dr. Zellmer truly wants everyone to succeed. Be prepared to spend a lot of time on mastering. The weekly quizzes weren't fun, but they were good prep for exams (questions were similar). I ended with a 75%, with curve a B-. 1220 with Zellmer is doable, but just be prepared for it to take up a lot of your time.

Dr. Zellmer truly sets his students up for success. Yes, he gives A LOT of homework and there are Sunday night quizzes, but these prepare you GREATLY for the exams. Zellmer's averages were the highest of all sections for a reason. Use the materials he tells you to and go to lecture! Highly recommend taking him. The curve was about 5-7% in the end.

CHEM 1220 your professor doesn't matter as long as its not Zellmer. Just read the textbook. Ended with a 96 before curve and I didn't go to a single lecture. Final was extremely easy and Midterms were as well. I highly recommend taking someone other than Zellmer because he has annoying Sunday night quizzes.

I really enjoyed Zellmer's lectures and don't understand why he gets so much flack for them. He is by far the best 1220 professor and prepares you for the midterms. The quizzes are good practice for the midterms. I hate chemistry but Zellmer helped me learn to like it.

Overall, Zellmer was a terrible lecturer, and a terrible human being. He gave quizzes on a SUNDAY NIGHT, which the class averages were 50-60%. His homework was graded for accuracy and due on weekend nights. Also, his lectures were useless, I had to stop going to lecture, and learn the material by myself at home. STEAR CLEAR OF ZELLMER.

Dr. Zellmer is a very nice guy, but his job of teaching is done poorly. The lectures were pointless, his notes are made up of every color you could possibly think of, he held sunday night quizzes 7pm-10pm (only professor to do this) and an insane amount of hw due every friday and saturday night (around 5 due for each night). Avoid at all costs!

A list of things Robert Zellmer does/has done:

Sunday night quizzes with a 60% average that will tank your grade and do not resemble the exams or homework (no other lecturer does this)
Insane amounts of homework graded for correctness
Mocks you for asking questions in lecture
My comment would get removed if I listed a certain other thing he did

Dr. Zellmer is overall a great teacher, but the rumors you hear about him being judgmental are true. I have never been more anxious in my life than in his lectures, but he is one of the better chem teachers. There is SO MUCH HOMEWORK, due Fridays and Saturdays, and the weekly quizzes on Sunday nights. Prepare to give up a lot of social gatherings.

Many people give him a lot of crap, but Dr. Zellmer is nice and if you put in the work you will do fine. The class moves really fast, but that's not his fault. Lectures are helpful and often have interesting demonstrations. Be prepared to spend a lot of time outside of class studying and practicing problems. Answers emails quickly.

This class will be extremely challenging and time-consuming. In comparison to 1220, the content is easier but I think just adjusting to the learning style and content of gen chem is the most difficult aspect. Zellmer may seem intimidating and impatient, but he goes out of his way for you to be able to access anything you need.
Just a bad professor, not good at teaching. Guided notes look like they were made by a 3rd grader with a new box of crayons with hundreds of colors. Good person. Nice guy. Bad teacher.

Professor went through content so fast it gave me whiplash. Had Sunday quizzes only open from 7pm-10pm every week. Was a huge waste of time cause they not only tanked your grade but were impossible to do well on. Also gave so much homework and he needed to realize that his class is not the only class students are taking.

Dr. Zellmer is a tough professor. I don't think he's a bad guy, but he doesn't seem to get that his students' lives don't revolve around chemistry. He does have a good sense of humor, which can make lecture interesting, but be prepared to go FAST in lecture. 

7pm quizzes on sunday suck. They are very difficult and barely resemble the weekly hw.

Dr. Zellmer is a very interesting man but I personally did not love his teaching style. Demos were fun but other than that, lectures did not help me at all in this course. Rather, labs and recitation with my incredible TA (Alexia Silva!) helped me the most. Oh, and quizzes on Sunday at 7PM EVERY WEEK broke my spirit. Would not recommend.

He assigned a lot of homework, which I wouldn't mind doing if he actually taught us the content. He went super fast over the content, gave quizzes every Sunday night, and also does not know how to use technology. He wasn't very nice and I did not learn very well from him at all. I am retaking the class with Dr. Stoltzfus and I am much happier.

Overall he is a very intriguing person. Almost pushing 80, runs on 3 hours of sleep every night typing out his badly structured emails that are painful to read. Has a superiority complex because of his 50+ of teaching experience. But hard, strict grader, gives tons of hw, horrible lecturing style, Sunday quizzes, if you have him, i'm so sorry

Zellmer may be THE worst professor Iv’e ever had, or heard of. Better off watching online videos than attending lecture. Suddenly, I am actually somewhat understanding content. If you attend class be ready to learn three weeks of content past what you need to know for an upcoming exam. 50% average for Sun quiz’s

Avoid this professor at all costs. All chem professors will be hard and possibly people youre not fond of but I wake up regretting not switching out of his class everyday. He gives 6 homework's every week all 45-60 minutes long that arent too hard but hes the only professor to assign Sunday quizzes which are NOTHING like the homework.

Lectures were often confusing as he sped through them so fast. LOTS of online MasteringChemistry homework, but the problems were doable if you paid attention in lecture. Also required weekly quizzes which apparently other sections of 1220 didn't have to do, which could tank your grade if you mess them up. I would recommend taking someone else.

His notes are written, not typed, and awful to follow. His lectures confuse me more than help. He assigns a ridiculous amount of homework on MasteringChemistry, graded for accuracy. He has Sunday night quizzes every week. Awful teacher, doesn't offer a Zoom option for quarantined students or post recordings; he doesn't care about his students.

DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS unless you are prepared to do quizzes on a Sunday night at 7 pm. Dude expects you to know about everything and tells you to do a ridiculous amount of work that does not help in understanding the content. I literally had to self-learn all materials. But I do give him credit for having twisted dark humor.

His overall demeanor is derogatory and condescending. Sends about 3 emails per day without fail, as well as occasional late-night emails. Assigns weekly quizzes that are only utilized in his section of Gen Chem 2. Overall disliked his course and elected to watch Dr. Stolzfus's youtube videos about the subjects we covered in order to understand.

The worst professor I had this past semester, he made my first semester of college a horrible experience. The unnecessary amount of work and time required for this class is horrible and I wouldn't recommend this professor to anyone.

Dr. Z is hands down best professor ive ever had...a LOT of people will crap on him as you can see in these reviews, but the guy is the most helpful teacher ive ever had. Go to his office hours and he'll stay overtime to help you. It's obvious he works hard to help students. You have to work for it though. You cant not work for it and then blame him

Dr. Zellmer sends a crap ton of emails with a lot of useless information. His lectures most of the time were very confusing especially if you have no previous knowledge of chemistry. Without reading the book, this class is extremely hard. There are quizzes every sunday and are barely counted towards the overall grade. Overall, he is a harsh grader.

Dr. Zellmer is incredibly harsh grader, he tries his best to prepare the students for the midterms and while he knows his stuff he expects everyone else to know the info like him. He also grades quizzes and mastering chem while other professors dont and his quizzes were at the least convenient times (also incredibly hard).

Zellmer has a very confusing teaching style. He is very straightforward about doing all the book problems and other assigned material. This however is hard to do when you are in other demanding stem courses. I did not have time to sit and do chem 3 hours every day. I got 60s on all the exams , my final grade percent was a 70 and that was a B-.

Zellmer is fantastic. He is stern but he makes funny jokes during 8am lecture which make it more bearable. He cares so much about his students and once emailed me back within five minutes on a Sunday night. This class is hard but he is always available and even has evening office hours. Quizzes 7-10pm on Sunday nights did suck though.

I can tell he's a good teacher, but his teaching style didn't work for me and a lot of the times it just feels like hes yelling at you at 8am and has no faith in his students. He is very accessible but since his style doesn't help me, the accessibility wasn't beneficial. Alright professor, but not someone I ever want to have again. Fus is better.
Chem 1210 itself is a tough subject. Feels like the workload is too much but it's actually really helpful for you to understand the class better.
Very straightforward in his grading and what needs to be completed over what topics. Lectures can get a bit confusing so read the book along with the topics to help with understanding.
A great professor, helped me out a lot. Although he sends an annoying amount of emails, its because he wants to help you pass. All around pretty good!

Probably the most helpful professor I've ever had. He holds a how to study session at the beginning of the semester, and Ive followed his strategy and it actually helps a lot. He gives soooo many resources to help his students, even though that means he'll send you a million emails a day. Its very obvious that he wants his students to pass.
absurd amount of homework and gives quizzes on holidays

gonna be honest, it's a lot of work. but it pays off. do what he tells you to do: read the textbook, do the end-of-chapter exercises, watch the prelectures AND go to lecture, and you'll get an A. people think he's tough, but he's just pushing you to do your best. he gives a lot of homework because it actually helps you learn.

Dr. Zellmer is hands down one of my favorite profs at OSU - CHEM 1220 over the summer semester was no joke but bearable with his dry humor and accessibility. Don't be intimidated by him or bad ratings. Belly on up to him, use him as a resource, and you won't be disappointed. Expect to work hard and be challenged while laughing along the way!

Dr. Zellmer is hands down the best professor I've ever had at OSU. His online teaching style is very engaging (he's a funny guy) and he makes his students a priority. He can be tough but that's the reason why his students do much better on exams than the average. He provides lots and lots of extra materials to help his students succeed

Dr. Zellmer is a decent professor. He can seem a bit intimidating but he knows his stuff well and will help if you ask for it. The chem dept. handles 1220 poorly: exams have minimal time, little credit for HW, & labs are a bit excessive. This class is graded hard but if you keep up w/all the work & put in time to study, you will not fail the class.

Dr. Zellmer is an AMAZING professor. he cares about the well-being of his students and truly wants them to succeed. yes, he is a bit intimidating, but he makes sure that you know all the concepts (plus more) that you need to learn in this class. he gives you so many resources to do well and even has his own website! he's also super funny

Chem1220 is a very difficult class for the average person. The class is very test heavy and the labs are tedious. Expect to put in a lot of time. That being said, Zellmer is a good professor but doesnt go out of his way to help his students succeed. Aim to be above average in the class and the curve will bring your grade up. Good luck!

Zellmer is hands down one of the best lecturers you will ever get, he knows what he's talking about and explains a topic clearly. He gets a rep for being a jerk, but he's just honest. There's no way you'll do well in 1250 if you don't read the textbook and do the homework. The class was hard but what can you expect from a combined chem class.
Nice man, needlessly difficult class. Get above an 85 for an A-.

Zellmer is a great lecturer, extremely organized, and maybe somewhat insane. The exams were rough because if they were rapid-fire multiple choice. You have to be able to rattle off problems quickly, which is why he tells you to do so much homework. Also be prepared to read his lengthy emails.

I took this class over the summer as an 8 week condensed class so the workload was awful, but going to Dr. Zellmer's lectures and office hours help so much. He seems scary, but if you actually put in the work then go talk to him, he'll be one of your favorite professors.

Dr. Zellmer has been the best professor I have had at OSU thus far. This class was extremely difficult and time consuming but if you attend his how to study meeting and do what he says, you'll have no problem passing. He does give out a lot of homework, but do every problem and read the book!

A very knowledgeable professor, who teaches the material well and covers nearly every detail you can think of. He gives things that are annoying like weekly quizzes and lots of homework, but it seems like he does so because he genuinely cares and wants you to pass. Read the textbook and do the recommended problems, and you can succeed.

Zellmer is pretty intense, especially during exams. Other than that, he knows what he is talking about and is a decent professor. Try to read the book before lecture, it will help as he goes kinda fast. Gen chem is hard and you really have to put in work in order to do well. If you do the homework and go to lecture you will come out (mostly) alive

This was by far the most difficult class I have ever taken, but Dr. Zellmer is aware of the course difficulty and tries to make it as bearable as possible. His website is extremely helpful with tips for the labs and for the "homework" assignments that you should definitely do. Dr. Zellmer is very caring and I actually enjoyed his lectures.

Dr. Zellmer makes you put the work in to get a good grade, but he provides you with all of the resources to be successful (practice tests/quizzes, supplemental explanations of concepts and calculations on his website). His lectures reflect the material on exams and are easy to follow, although fast paced. He's also hilarious with some of his jokes!

Zellmer's lectures generally consist of him going through math problems without explaining where many of his numbers come from. After lecture it usually feels like you have just been yelled at for an hour. There is a LOT of homework required for this class, the majority of it being assigned right before exams so it is hard to find time to study.

Possibly the worst professor I had in college. He is clearly into himself and chemistry more than he is in helping people understand the material. I went to his office hours to get help and he told me i was too stupid to pass the class and should consider switching majors from engineering to education or something. Not a nice guy
God awful teacher. Not clear and clearly doesnt care about his students well-being. Take anyone else.

Chem 1250 is extremely difficult but I guess it's not entirely Zellmer's fault that the class is so hard. He gives you plenty of practice material but you cannot fall behind. His exams are difficult and you need to go really fast to finish all the problems on them. Also, he wears a mic during lecture and it feels he is yelling at you for an hour.

1250 was definitely one of the toughest classes I've taken at OSU, but it would have been a whole lot worse without a professor like Zellmer. He cares a ton about his student's success; he holds helpful review sessions before tests, sends emails out all the time with help, and is very accessible with office hours. Tough class, great professor.

Dr. Zellmer is in a tough position. The 1250 class covers 20 chapters in a single semester, but that's not his fault. Zellmer though makes the best out of the situation. He provides every resource necessary to succeed (lecture notes, hw problems, practice tests), so its really about whether or not you're prepared to put in the work to succeed.

While Zellmer is known to be the hardest professor for the General Chemistry sequence, he truly respects and helps his students succeed. His notes are outstanding and will go out of his way at midnight to send emails to the entire class and to individuals who have questions. Do not fall behind - there is a lot of material to understand.
Tough but fair. He provides a lot of practice material for exams and quizzes.

Zellmer does not have a good reputation, but he does care about his students. He clearly spends a lot of time on his lectures and makes sure he is available for office hours. His exams are extremely difficult as they require a very deep understanding of the material and he expects a lot from students. Get ready for 10-15 emails a day from him.

Zellmer is by far the hardest professor I have ever had, but it is not because he is teaching wrong material like other professors in the chem department at OSU. I am retaking chem1220 in the SU and his exams are harder because they are not standardized like during AU and SP semester. I would not want another professor because hes that smart/good.
You can't simply 'learn' material. Be ready to apply it and have a deep understanding of it in order to do well.

Zellmer deserves the reputation he's given. That doesn't mean he is a bad teacher, but make sure to go to class and study pretty much everyday, even if its for an hour. Definitely go to his "how to study" classes. There's a pretty good curve (10 points overall), so just do above average on midterms and ace your lab reports and you should be fine.

The best professor I have ever had. His class is tough, but he cares a lot about his students and is so passionate about the subject he teaches. He is so knowledgeable and an extremely hard working professor; His hard work made me want to work even harder. He is always available, day and night, to help his students with any problems.

When you sign up for Zellmer's 1250 class, you might also want to open up amazon and buy a bottle of lube to apply before each lab, quiz, and midterm. This class moves so fast they should install seatbelts on the chairs in the lecture hall. Is this class possible? Yes. Just be ready to have zero free time. Social life? HA! forget about it. Avoid.
Constantly uses midnight emails to send out important course information; grades lab reports using outdated website

Bad things: Recommended homework is impossible to get finished. The weekly quizzes are graded very hard. Weed-out course with a high level of commitment. Good things: He cares about you learning. He gives EXCELLENT premidterm reviews. You will learn a lot because you will need to in order to pass. Responds to emails immediately. Scary smart prof.

Chem II is a difficult class, but professor Zellmer explains the content in a clear, understandable, manner. He uses a lot of slides in his class and all of them are available for students online to look at or follow along, as desired. He seems to care about the material and student achievement.

I took AP CHEM in high school and greatly helped me. You definitely dont need it to succeed. I was able to skip lectures, although I dont recommend it. Learn how to take his tests, dont learn his content. Hes well informed and loves chemistry. I learned how the tests work and finessed my way thru. My 91.38 turned out to be an A (4.0).

Dr. Zellmer is a good professor. People complain because the class is hard, and it is because of the fact that it's Chemistry 1 and a majority of 2 combined in one semester. If you keep up with homework assignments, as well as go to lectures and office hours, you should be fine. You don't need to have taken AP Chem to take this class.

All tests are hard and averages are about 60 to 70. While he is a really a smart and nice guy. Tons of emails every week. I tried to send him emails later than 1 am before exams and he replied in 15 minutes. I am reviewing the final exam tomorrow and writing my comments. Will take his class again next semester and have enrolled in.

He sent like 30 emails before school started. He will continue to send lots of emails. He will challenge you to study on your own by making the tests really difficult. Great weed out class. He's really helpful if you go to office hours and he's really nice if you get to know him. Don't judge him by the difficult of the class :)
Super cynical, but communicates information well, but chem 1250 is overall an insanely hard class and blatantly a huge engineering weed-out. Do not take it and 1172 at the same time.
His class is the most difficult

His exams are pretty hard and the homework can never be finished. But, he is a good teacher, always accessible in his office, answering questions. I highly recommend you to read the book thoroughly and do as many homework problems as possible. His PDF notes do not cover everything in his exams but the book does. Also, understand each equation!

This class is hard. And he lets you know it the first day. He is a decent lecturer, but I hated labs w/ a passion, he came in and barked at everyone. Lab reports and the online scoring was a nightmare, he is extremely picky. I only did well due to practicing multiple old midterms and keeping up. Ended w/ an 86 and curved to an A- (92ish)

Overall, he is very knowledgeable and wants you to be as well. However, this is not a class you can skate by on studying the night before. He requires constant learning and studying and his tests are meant to be extremely difficult. There is a curve but it may or may not favor you.

He thinks himself  Einstein. One day he told that, he finished an unfinished work of Rutherford, and he will prove nucleus revolves around the electrons in contrary to the opinion of our textbook BLB . He can do this kind of research in his lab but this is a 1250 freshman class. I strongly advise my fellow buckeyes not to take this class.

I got an 80%. He curved a little less than 10%. He will come into lab and yell at you. He will send you 26  emails before the class STARTS and 1000 more throughout. Don't load up on credit hours this semester chem is  going to take your life away.  He isn't afraid to say your questions are stupid and you are. Beware of Chem 1250.

Overall, I'd say Dr. Zellmer is a decent professor for a difficult course. He is definitely a little quirky, but he is very dedicated to his job. If you can manage to do all the homework problems by pacing yourself and doing some every day, you should pass with no problem. Those who have difficulty in this class most likely don't do any of the hw

The only thing difficult about this class is the amount of material he throws at you. If you put in 15 hours a week reading the book and doing homework you will do fine and not be stressed out. I didn't even go to class because I couldn't understand his lectures, I just read the book a ton.

Zellmer's class was no joke and it was hard, but I learned so much last semester! You MUST read the book for every section and do tons of book problems, because if you don't put this necessary work in you won't pass his exams. His exams are very difficult, but if you do the work you should be ok. He's a really nice guy and super willing to help!

Unless you are very talented about learning material from the textbook, this is going to be a challenging course. Thanks to the engineering department, Zellmer has more material to teach then anyone should have to learn in one semester. The lectures fly, expect to spend tons of time outside of class reviewing material from the textbook

drzellmer is a cool guy with a good sense of humor, but as a teacher he can be diabolical. the final cumulative exam was easy after his class, so that's good, but his midterms (all three) were so ridiculously hard with MANY trick questions that it was common to get Ds on all three midterms and then an A on the final because it wasn't written by him

zellmer is a cool guy with a good sense of humor, but as a teacher he can be diabolical. the final cumulative exam was easy after his class, so that's good, but his midterms (all three) were so ridiculously hard with MANY trick questions that it was common to get Ds on all three midterms and then an A on the final because it wasn't written by him

he is a very odd man. he is very set in his ways and will repeat the same things a million times. some people are scared of him but he really does want people to do well and really loves chemistry. He is very predicable and quirky. has a kind of dark sense of humor but is often funny not trying to be just because of his oddities.
Zellmer is a tough professor, but if you are willing to put in a ton of time an effort you will do well and know the material well.

Great lecturer/professor. Clearly is interested in the information and wants you to succeed. This class is no joke however, and it will require a lot of work outside of class to do well. He is very intimidating at first but I think the point of this was to prepare you for the amount of work that is necessary. Good prof, would take again.
No matter what class you take with Dr. Zellmer, expect to have no time for your other classes. Be expected to give up anything relatively social in your life.

Gives quality lectures, is a very clear teacher, really wants to help students learn the difficult material. Sends long but very clear and helpful emails very often. One of the hardest and most stressful classes I've ever taken, but not because of Zellmer. Tests are hard, but the class is fairly curved at the end.

This was a tough class and you must be prepared to do the work. You will have to spend hours every day studying and doing homework to receive a good grade. His tests have trick questions and are tough to complete in the time given.

Dr. Zellmer  is an extremely strict and tough guy. The point to obtain a good credit for this class is to work hard and keep pushing throughout  the semester. If you  wish to get A,you have to finish every problem he assigned on the textbook(around 60   problems each chapter) and finish his practice exams.

Zellmer's name is well known around campus for his unique character. He is very strict, and can be very harsh, but he knows his chemistry. The course will require a lot out of you, but he does everything in his power to help, just so long as you check the syllabus, and his website, and all that before going to him. Also, he looks like Count Dooku.

CHEM 1250 is tough, but people are quick to blame Zellmer for their poor performance. But they shouldn't because Zellmer is a quality professor that really knows his stuff. There is a lot of material, but If you pay attention in lecture, do the practice problems, and do your part to learn the material, you will realize how good of a professor he is

He cares. He's not warm and fuzzy and he's got a very direct blunted personality but he really does care. Do the homework problems, read the book, if you don't get something don't just skip over it chances are it will come back to haunt you if not now then in a more advanced class.

This class is no joke. But Dr. Zellmer is an excellent professor. The key is to DO THE PRACTICE PROBLEMS he assigns you. I did not, and I learned this the hard way. The exams are hard, but the curve is helpful. if you keep up on studying and DO THE PRACTICE PROBLEMS you will be fine.

Zellmer's class is by far one of the hardest classes I've ever taken. I easily spent 10 hours a week outside of class doing homework and studying. That being said, if you listen in lecture & do what he tells you to do, you'll get a lot out of it. You have to work hard, but if you put in the effort you should get a good grade.

He thinks he's funny, crams every thing in one lecture. its doesn't have a recitation which is the dumbest thing since it combines chem 1 and 2. Osu pretty much makes Engineering students take the course. the TA's are stuck up. If you ask for help, the TA's and zellmer talk down to you and make you feel dumb.

The worst professor I've ever had. Rude, thinks he's a lot better than everyone else, leaves everyone wondering what he is talking about. I took CHEM 1220 before this class (due to confusion) at a post secondary liberal arts college and I found it so much easier than this course and I didn't know half the information for the course.

Chemistry 1250 was the most demanding class I have ever taken: All the lectures contribute to the quizzes, curricular tests, and weekly labs with very long lab reports to make. That's why I couldn't have passed it without Mr. Zellmer: He covered everything we needed to know from the book, and used detailed notes we all could access.
He puts the notes online, but you have to do more than just attend lecture. Make sure you do the homework in the book even though it is not for a grade.
Horrible teacher with rushed lectures and too much expected work for any average student to handle
He expects you to do lots of reading and homework. Always sends out many emails explaining labs or questions. Explain concepts clearly. Detailed webpage where you can find everything you need.

He is wonderful. The chemistry department and really most science related disciplines require a lot from you but if you put in the work and make sure you read the book you should do well. Read the book and do the assigned homework problems it's that simple.

If this was your only class you were taking, you'd have a chance to do well. Expects people to have a level of knowledge not far below his on the material to do well on the exams. He's a nice guy and will help pretty much anytime outside of class, as long as you've gone over EVERYTHING related to that topic beforehand.

Zellmer is definitely the hardest professor I've had at OSU.  On the first couple days he tries to intimidate you by saying the average of his class is a C and only 10% of the people that pass the class get A- or higher.  Just to put that in perspective, I was above the class average on every quiz, lab, and exam and only received a B-. Best of luck

Class is a joke, if you are hoping to learn chemistry, you are in the wrong class. It is very easy to do well in this class if you focus on understanding how he writes test questions. Pathetic trick questions.  If you know where to look online you can find over a dozen previous exams dating back to 2013 and their solutions and see his tricks.

He stated in the first week of class that 21-28 hours a week of homework for his class is required to get a decent grade in his class. The lectures are long and he goes through material quickly - the lectures are large and students don't have a chance to ask questions. During the semester he has sent more than 150 emails to the course.

1250 was not too bad, especially after taking AP chem in high school.  I didn't have to do much studying to do well in the class, and the only homework is weekly lab reports.  Zellmer is a good lecturer, and tries to make it interesting.  He's there to help if u need it, and is actually a nice guy.
professor is a nice guy, but this class,en,well, i should say if you are not chemistry crazy funs or didn't take chemistry AP before, you should take 1210 and 1220. drop before it get you crazy.

i visited dr. zellmer in office hours at least once a week, he is a fantastic although extremely intimidating. this was by far the hardest class i've ever taken. you really need to put in a lot of time and effort into this class in order to succeed. it's very self driven so if you don't put in outside work you will fail.

He is a Nice Professor. Very clear in his Lectures. Tests are usually bit harder. But everything in the test is covered in the class. The only thing is that the Lab reports are time taking. His website is really helpful, you will find every answer to your question regarding the subject.

Really great professor. He's intimidating and strict but it's really all for your benefit. When it comes to being helpful he gets a 100%. His infamous emails are really helpful if you get over how annoying they are and he clearly lays out exactly what he expects you to know. Do the work (which there will be a lot of) and it will pay off.
Chem 1250 is a combination of 1210 and 1220, this class is fast and has no recitation and is only 4 credit hours. This class is graded on a class curve.

He is a very dedicated professor. You have to attend his lectures and put in effort to do well. He explains concepts very well, although class moves at a very fast pace. Its a time-consuming class but as long as you put in effort, you'll reap what you sow.
the lectures are so annoying in the sense that it feels like he is shouting at you the entire time, expect more difficult tests than you expect.

Your class grade is heavily dependent on the TA you get, Not the professor. That said Zellmer is a good lecturer however his class is Infamously difficult. Prepare for LATE Night chem reports and tests that will make you question if you've even been showing up to the right classroom all this time. Buckle up buttercup. Take it over chem 1210 & 1220

1250 was the hardest class I have taken, if you are taking at the same time as math 1172, don't, you won't pass one or both of them. Zellmer will help, but you have to go in knowing exactly what your questions are or you will walk out more confused than before.

Zellmer was probably the best professor i had so far. He is keen on making sure you learn chemistry. His lectures are very clear and helpful, and sometimes can be really fun. I see why people are complaining about the difficulty of class, but if you put in the effort, you'll get what you deserve, hes a very fair person.

Extremely hard class. Expect to read everyday and spend a lot of time outside of the class doing the homework problems. The labs are very tough as well and take a lot of time to write the whole report.

Zellmer is really good at teaching the concepts and is willing to help you as long as you meet him halfway but his class (1250) is not going to be easy unless you had AP Chem (like me). You will need to study out of class almost everyday if you have no previous chem experience and you will need to do most of the homework but if you do its not awful

Chemistry 1250 is by far the most difficult class I've taken to date. A lot material is covered at a fast rate each lecture, which made it difficult for me to keep up and retain all of it. My grade primarily depended on how much studying and practice I put in outside of class. This class must be first priority. Covers 18 chapters in one semester.

Zellmer is smart, funny, and willing to help if you're willing to put in the work. His lectures are very clear and informative and he offers plenty of review and supplemental material on his website. A lot of info was covered in this course, so make sure you go to every lecture so you don't fall behind. Quizzes and exams can be very rushed.

He sends so many emails that, while helpful, can be a bit much. I have never met him personally, so I cannot comment on his helpfulness if you actually go to him, but his website spells out the labs quite clearly and I am not sure if I would know how to use Microsoft Excel without him. Don't skip lab, it will make everything a pain.
He is a good professor. Straight forward. Very helpful. Read the email because they help a lot. Especially with lab.
Great class. It really turned me on to the possibilities in chemistry

Notes are very clear and he gives examples that makes the content easier to understand. Sort of intimidating in class, but if you ask him question after class, he will explain the question really patiently. One of my favorite professors :)
Review his lecture notes again and again!
Zellmer is intimidating but a very good lecturer. He goes fast through the content, so make sure you keep up with homework, even though it isn't graded.
You're basically guaranteed a higher grade in any other lecture
He is a tough grader. This class is tough but you have to take it.
tough

You will leave his class with a great understanding of the material. That said his exams are a lot tougher than all of the other lectures, and he gives quizzes that are harshly graded (other classes get participation points for recitation) He uses the tests and quizzes to force you to study. Would recomenget another teacher and attend his lectures.
He's e-mails were so confusing. He's also very emotional. famous of getting mad.  Love speaking ill of students.
Dr. Zellmer is a very good professor.  He demands the best of you.  He is almost always available and is extremely helpful, but you must be willing to work hard.

Zellmer's class was the hardest I took my first year, but more due to the amount of material covered rather than the content being hard to understand. He has good in class examples and is helpful if you talk to him. He puts a lot of material on his website, which is extremely useful. As long as you don't fall behind, this class is passable.
Interesting professor who makes lecture interesting. His quizzes and exams are very tough though and are not likely to be passed without many many hours of intense studying.
Hardest chem professor at Ohio State.

Dr. Zellmer is probably one of the most interesting professors I have had.  His class is very difficult, but I always looked forward to it.  He gives excellent examples in lecture, and almost always has interesting demonstrations to proveexplain concepts.  Even though I barely got a C in his class, I would definitely take a class with him again.

Best teacher I have had at OSU; however, he expects the best out of you. Can come off as a bit mean in class, but if you go to his office hours, you will find him helpful. Go to lectures, take good notes, and don't be afraid to ask questions.
Good Teacher, but extremely difficult class. Exams and quizzes are very difficult, although not impossible. Would not reccomend taking the class with him

Great teacher, but the amount of material you have to cover is just awful. Definitely the toughest class I took my first two years. Prepare for the quizzes since they add up to an exam grade, and study your butt off for the exams. Lab reports are a pain and are graded pretty strictly. The final is cumulative so you can imagine what that is like.

Great teacher, willing to work with students if they come to him and have put the time in. The class is really challenging, but if you studying the practice exams and understand the questions then you will be above the curve average. Homework wasn't mandatory, but doing it certainly helps!

Dr.Zellmer will certainly teach you the material, I really feel like I understand chemistry, but despite studying more for this class than any other his ruthless grading scale makes getting an A nearly impossible. He is the toughest teacher I have ever had, would not recommend unless you are prepared for a terrible semester.

Zellmer is a great lecturer but a poor overall professor. His in-class demonstrations and explanations are always helpful, but if you ask him a question outside of the lecture hall setting he can be really condescending and unpleasant. In terms of labs and quizzes, he makes things unreasonably complicated and grades unreasonably harshly.
ok, definitely hard for my friends, but i have been going to probably 50% of the lectures and i'm doing all right. (all right = 85%) hoping for a generous class-curve.

One of the best teachers I've had. His office door is always open and it's smart to take advantage of that and ask lots of questions! I couldn't keep up so I dropped but if you're willing to put in the work and if you understand chemistry well then you'll be fine.

DR. ZELLMER IS THE BEST PROFESSOR I HAVE EVER HAD, HANDS DOWN. He genuinely cares about his students and wants them to succeed if they put in the work.  His class is fairly difficult and his teaching style comes off as a little combative. Don't be scared to approach him! His office door is almost always open and he is very receptive to questions.
Just don't if you don't have to

Great professor, very organized and controlled. He enjoys intimidating you but dont fret, he says you HAVE to study 3 hours a day to do well but i didnt, nor did i even do homework and was able to make a c. I had a good chance at a b but the final destroyed me. Lab was hands down the worst part. Quizzes were difficult

Most helpful professor I had so far. Class was tough and required a lot of work 3hrs every day . At the beginning of the semester he will hold out of class meetings on how to study for the course,  highly recommend attending one. Keep up with the class and do all the hwk problems. Dont be afraid to visit him during office hrs as he is very helpful.

I have never and probably will never have another professor as dedicated as Dr. Zellmer. The class is difficult, but he challenges his students to truly learn the information. If you meet him halfway, you should be successful and get a better chemistry experience than you'd expect going in.

Dr. Zellmer is the most helpful professor I have ever had and probably ever will have. His website is ridiculously helpful and he sends an outrageous amount of emails: every email is full of helpful hints! He gives you everything you need to succeed. You will get what you earn.
Very Helpful Professor, although  can seem intimidating.  The Class is alot of info. Do some homework every night and keep up with class and you will be fine.

He is a pretty good chemistry teacher, but he is very arrogant and degrading to students. His classes are tough and require you to read, take notes, understand lecture, and spend a ton of time on your labs. His classes take a lot of time to prepare for, and you are expected to treat the class like you are an actually chemist.

I took his class 1250 my fish year. Next semester( current soph) I am taking 1220. Let me tell you something very important. His class is hard but If you get around B or get above average, classes like chem 1220 is a JOKE . IN my opinion you should take chem 1210 and 1220 instead of chem 1250. :)

He expects a ton out of his students, and if you don't put in the effort, you will not pass, but if you approach him he is very willing to help.  Lots of e-mails.  I do not advise taking his class freshman year, but he is a decent teacher for people already adjusted to college life.

Very helpful professor, also very good-natured toward those who put in a lot of effort. He has a strict and overbearing demeanor, but he really has the desire to help students succeed. Be warned, this class will require an astounding amount of time if you want to pass and is extremely fast-paced.

One of the best professors I have had at Ohio State. Really makes you understand the material. Great guy despite his intimidating demeanor. If you keep up with the studying and practice problem, you will be fine in his class. If you fall behind even a little, it will be hard to catch up again.
Awesome professor. If you know the material well you will do well on the exams. Quizzes are more difficult, but prepare you for the exam well.
Zellmer is da man!

Even though this class is the hardest things in the whole world, Dr. Zellmer really cares about the students. He will take the time to sit with each and every student no matter how long it takes until you understand something. As long as you study and go to class, he will be nice to you. If you don't do anything, life will be very hard for you.

Dr Zellmer is an awesome professor he really knows everything about the material he is teaching. On the other hand this is by far the hardest of the chem 1220 classes. He gives you at least three hours of homework a night and his exams are hard. Overall he was the best chem teacher for pre med though.
Hard but fair. He is a very good teacher and he cares ALOT. Also, he's pretty funny. I got a B in the class and I studied an alright amount. If you study hard then an A in not out of reach.

Dr.Zellmer is ridiculously helpful. He is constantly sending emails with helpful hints for labs and homework. Chemistry is a difficult course and you get out of it what you put into it. Dr.Zellmer provides the resources to do well. Exams are fair (you do well if you know what you're doing). I'd highly recommend any chemistry course with Dr.Zellmer.

Dr. Zellmer is a really good teacher. His class is not easy, so you will need to do the homework and study a lot. He is so willing to help and goes out of his way to make sure students understand the material. I would highly recommend him as a chemistry teacher. He posts notes online, but GO TO LECTURE because its very helpful!

Dr Zellmer himself is a very good teacher and puts a ridiculous amount of effort into helping students (answering questions, emails, conducting reviews on Sundays). He makes practice exams that are identical to the tests themselves.1250 goes by fast, don't get behind. To get a good grade you will need to study your butt off. Class=6cr in my opinion

Dr. Zellmer is intimidating at first but he really is a great professor. If you need help, he will help you and he is actually kind of funny. He expects a lot but you also learn a lot. Put in a decent amount of time and do the practice exams and you'll be fine!

I should have taken 1200 first.  I may have to retake, but Dr. Zellmer really a great Professor.  He tells you everything you need to know right up front. You just need to work for it and you need to read the text book.  I don't recommend working during the week or taking two other lab courses like I did.   Good luck!
Dr. Zellmer is absolutely a great teacher, but his lectures kind run really fast. Not recommend to international student. But good choice for native students who want to learn things.
